guide.title: Gentoo Guide to USE flags
guide.abstract: This guide introduces you to the ultimate tool for customizing Gentoo -- USE settings. Not only is there a description of each USE flag in current use, there is also a helpful guide to help you to determine which USE flags you will need to use.

section.title: What is the use of USE flags anyway?

body.p: One of the things which attracted me, as a user, to Gentoo was the fact that it is a highly customisable distribution. The fact that it is a source based distribution allows the user complete control over what kinds of features and support are built in to the installed applications. Moreover, the idea of bloat reduction appealed to me -- I like not having to install things which I do not really need.

And how, exactly, does Gentoo achieve this? By defining USE settings. Essentially, these are keywords that define options used on a system-wide basis to configure applications during their respective compilation procedures.
Of course, Gentoo defines a set of safe default flags for you. You will find these in your /etc/make.profile/make.defaults file.
From the Gentoo-1.4_rc2 release, the USE settings are:
body.pre: USE="xv slang readline gpm berkdb mmx 3dnow gdbm tcpd pam libwww ssl nls arts perl python esd gif imlib sdl oggvorbis gnome gtk X qt kde motif opengl avi png tiff gif"
body.warn:
Instead of writing to this file, as I can see many of you scrambling to do, it is advisable procedure to edit your /etc/make.conf file
In that file, you will see:
body.p: You would uncomment it by removing the # and adding your own custom USE flags to that string between the quotes.
body.impo: Remember that -flag disables a flag and flag adds a flag. If a flag is neither in /etc/make.profile/make.defaults nor in /etc/make.conf then its functionality is disabled.
body.p: Simply uncomment that, and add whatever other flags you want to add. "But what if I want to remove things from the make.defaults file?" I hear you ask. That is simply done by putting "-flag" in your /etc/make.conf file. Mine, for example, looks like this:
body.pre: USE="-gnome -kde qt -arts -nls python perl oggvorbis opengl sdl -postgres jpeg png truetype xml xml2 dvd avi aalib mpeg encode fbcon mmx"
body.p: Now that you know how to enable extra flags, and disable existing flags, let us examine what these flags actually do.

body.note: If you want to add a use flag, add it to use.desc and upload it to CVS. use.desc is what this list is generated from.
